# saeonobsr <img src="saeon_hex.png" align="right" alt="" width="120" />

<!-- badges: start -->
<!-- badges: end -->

saeonobsr provides functions to query available datasets and download selected datasets from the SAEON observations database.  


## Installation

You can install the latest version of saeonobsr from [GitHub](https://github.com/GMoncrieff/saeonobsr) with:

``` r
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("GMoncrieff/saeonobsr")
```
## Authorisation

To use saeonobsr you need to first register an account SAEON observations database. Once registered you need to login and retrieve an API token from [https://observations.saeon.ac.za/account/token](https://observations.saeon.ac.za/account/token). This token will be valid for 1 month.

## Quickstart

This is a basic example which shows you a typical usage pattern.  

Before starting set your api access token using `Sys.setenv(OBSDB_KEY = "xxx")`.  

The code below lists all datasets available for th Cape Peninsula, South Africa, and downloads daily minimum temperature data for a single site

```{r example}
library(saeonobsr)
library(dplyr)
library(sf)

#create spatial bounds
#done using geojson.io
region <- '{
  "type": "FeatureCollection",
  "features": [
    {
      "type": "Feature",
      "properties": {},
      "geometry": {
        "type": "Polygon",
       "coordinates": [[[
              18.25927734375,
              -34.363843538830665
            ],[
              18.571014404296875,
              -34.363843538830665
            ],[
              18.571014404296875,
              -33.87839688404626
            ],[
              18.25927734375,
              -33.87839688404626
            ],[
              18.25927734375,
              -34.363843538830665
            ]]]}}]
}'
#create sf object
bounds<-st_read(region,quiet = TRUE)

#get a list of available datasets
#then filter to a selected site and observation type
datasets <- viewDatasets(extent=bounds,spatial = FALSE) %>%
      filter(siteName == 'Constantiaberg') %>%
      filter(description == 'Air Temperature - Daily Minimum - Degrees Celsius')

#retrieve the selected datasets for 2019
start = '2019-01-01'
end='2019-12-31'
obs <- getDatasets(datasets,startDate=start,endDate=end)
head(obs)

#filter 
```
